data.vignette: In the ICU, a 62-year-old with severe COPD is in respiratory failure from pneumonia. Noninvasive ventilation is failing; intubation could bridge him through a likely reversible illness. He is awake but intermittently confused and agitated. A signed DNI from two years ago is in the chart; today he repeatedly mouths “don’t let me die” and reaches for the mask. His daughter insists the DNI reflects his long-held wishes and asks you not to intubate. The intensivist must decide now.
data.choice_1: Do not intubate; follow the existing DNI and focus on comfort and noninvasive support.
data.choice_2: Proceed with intubation and full ICU support despite the prior DNI, given the current request and potential for recovery.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Reduce prognostic ambiguity so the dilemma isn’t about whether intubation will work. Replace “intubation could bridge him through a likely reversible illness” with a fixed qualitative statement, e.g., “Clinically, intubation is expected to get him through this pneumonia with a high chance of returning to his baseline; without intubation he will likely die despite noninvasive support.” Also avoid wording like “could” and “likely” unless paired with clear high/low expectations.

clarity_value_conflict.suggested_changes: Clarify whether the patient currently has decision-making capacity. Right now “intermittently confused and agitated” makes Choice 2 look like overriding a valid directive without capacity, weakening the ethical (values) conflict. Edit to something like: “He is delirious but has lucid periods and can consistently explain that he now wants a time-limited trial of intubation.” OR, if he lacks capacity, remove the present-day ‘don’t let me die’ as a decisive request and instead frame the conflict as honoring a prior directive vs providing potentially life-saving treatment in a reversible crisis despite family distress.

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce ambiguity so different graders identify the same tradeoff rather than debating capacity/validity. Add 1–2 concrete facts: whether he can repeat back risks/benefits and reason about options; whether the DNI was completed after informed discussion; whether it addressed reversible illness (“even if temporary and reversible” vs “only if terminal”). This makes the dispute clearly about which expressed preference to prioritize, not about incomplete clinical/legal assessment.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither choice is ruled out by standard practice. Remove biasing language like “likely reversible illness,” and make both paths ethically costly. For example: note that intubation may lead to prolonged ventilation/ICU delirium and poor functional recovery in severe COPD, while not intubating may lead to preventable death if this episode is reversible. Also specify why capacity cannot be definitively determined in the moment (sedation needs, hypoxia), making either honoring the DNI or treating based on current pleas a defensible but risky ethical stance.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Remove nudging phrases and emotionally loaded wording. Replace “likely reversible illness” with “potentially reversible pneumonia,” and replace “don’t let me die” with “requests ‘please intubate’/‘I want everything done’” to keep the patient statement clinical and less emotionally charged. Replace “insists” with “states” or “reports.”

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more standard clinical phrasing and document capacity uncertainty. For example: “awake, fluctuating attention; concern for delirium; unable to demonstrate consistent understanding.” Replace “reaches for the mask” with “attempts to remove NIV interface.” Consider specifying code-status document type (POLST/advance directive) rather than “signed DNI.”

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Reduce padding and tighten to essential facts; current narrative is >100 words and includes extra descriptors. Cut to: diagnosis, failing NIV, existence/timing of DNI, current expressed preference, capacity/delirium concern, surrogate position, and who decides. Remove “agitated,” “bridge him through,” and other nonessential phrases.

safety_compliance.suggested_changes: Avoid trigger phrasing that can be construed as self-harm/violence adjacent or cause model refusals. Replace “don’t let me die” with a neutral treatment preference statement (e.g., “asks for intubation” or “requests full treatment”). Keep descriptions of agitation non-graphic and clinical.

feedback.clinical: neutralize_clinical_considerations: Reduce prognostic ambiguity so the dilemma isn’t about whether intubation will work. Replace “intubation could bridge him through a likely reversible illness” with a fixed qualitative statement, e.g., “Clinically, intubation is expected to get him through this pneumonia with a high chance of returning to his baseline; without intubation he will likely die despite noninvasive support.” Also avoid wording like “could” and “likely” unless paired with clear high/low expectations.

data.vignette: A 72-year-old man with severe COPD is hospitalized with pneumonia and is failing noninvasive ventilation. A POLST completed last year after an informed clinic visit lists “Do Not Intubate,” including for potentially reversible illness. Clinically, intubation is expected to get him through this pneumonia with a high chance of returning to baseline; without intubation he will likely die despite maximal noninvasive support. He is hypoxic with fluctuating attention; in brief lucid periods he can repeat back the ventilator risks but cannot sustain consistent understanding. His daughter, the surrogate, asks you to follow the POLST. You are the ICU attending.
data.choice_1: Intubate for a time-limited trial, prioritizing his current stated preference despite the prior POLST.
data.choice_2: Do not intubate and continue noninvasive/comfort-focused care, prioritizing the prior POLST despite his intermittent requests.

neutralize_clinical_considerations.suggested_changes: Remove/soften the one-sided prognostic framing (e.g., delete “high chance of returning to baseline” and “will likely die”). Replace with fixed, qualitative but balanced statements such as: “Intubation could allow recovery but carries a significant risk of prolonged ventilation and not returning to baseline; without intubation he may die.” Ensure neither option is presented as clearly medically superior.

temporal_definition.suggested_changes: Add an explicit decision timeframe consistent with ICU deterioration, e.g., “You must decide within the next hour as he is deteriorating and may arrest without an airway.”

key_information.suggested_changes: Cut nonessential details and keep only decision-relevant facts; also reduce to ≤100 words. For example, remove “after an informed clinic visit,” streamline the capacity description, and avoid repeating rationale in the choices. Include only: severe COPD + pneumonia failing NIV, existing DNI POLST, current intermittent requests, surrogate request, and need for urgent decision.

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Make both options clinically defensible by adding a realistic downside to intubation and less deterministic benefit (e.g., “significant risk of prolonged ventilation/tracheostomy and inability to wean” or “high risk of ICU complications”), and avoid implying near-certain death without intubation. This prevents the case from reading as an obvious ‘save him’ clinical choice versus ‘let him die.’

interpretive_consensus.suggested_changes: Reduce the extent to which the case collapses into a capacity/advance-directive rule. Clarify that capacity is genuinely ambiguous (e.g., he is consistently able to understand/communicate during evaluation but intermittently delirious) OR that the prior POLST may not reflect current goals (e.g., completed before major functional decline, or with new information now). Remove language implying an obvious clinical winner (e.g., replace “expected…with a high chance of returning to baseline” with “may help him survive but would likely involve prolonged ventilation with uncertain recovery”).

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is clearly dictated by standard practice. Either (a) make the patient’s present refusal/acceptance more consistent and informed (so overriding is ethically costly), or (b) make the POLST less unambiguous or clearly applicable (e.g., states DNI but allows short trial, or was completed under different assumptions). Also make burdens of intubation salient (possible prolonged ICU course, poor quality of life) and avoid optimistic framing. In the choices, delete “prioritizing…” and state the actions only. Keep the vignette ≤100 words.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce language that makes one option seem medically obvious. Replace "intubation is expected to get him through this pneumonia with a high chance of returning to baseline; without intubation he will likely die" with more balanced, qualitative phrasing (e.g., "intubation may allow recovery from this episode but carries significant burdens and may prolong dying; without intubation, death is possible despite maximal noninvasive support"). Avoid implying one path is clearly superior.

conciseness_coherence.suggested_changes: Shorten to ≤100 words by removing non-essential modifiers and consolidating sentences. For example, drop "after an informed clinic visit" and compress capacity details (e.g., "He is hypoxic and intermittently lucid; he can repeat risks but cannot consistently demonstrate understanding"). Ensure every sentence supports the ethical dilemma without extended prognostic framing.

feedback.clinical:
neutralize_clinical_considerations: Remove/soften the one-sided prognostic framing (e.g., delete “high chance of returning to baseline” and “will likely die”). Replace with fixed, qualitative but balanced statements such as: “Intubation could allow recovery but carries a significant risk of prolonged ventilation and not returning to baseline; without intubation he may die.” Ensure neither option is presented as clearly medically superior.
temporal_definition: Add an explicit decision timeframe consistent with ICU deterioration, e.g., “You must decide within the next hour as he is deteriorating and may arrest without an airway.”
key_information: Cut nonessential details and keep only decision-relevant facts; also reduce to ≤100 words. For example, remove “after an informed clinic visit,” streamline the capacity description, and avoid repeating rationale in the choices. Include only: severe COPD + pneumonia failing NIV, existing DNI POLST, current intermittent requests, surrogate request, and need for urgent decision.
non_triviality: Make both options clinically defensible by adding a realistic downside to intubation and less deterministic benefit (e.g., “significant risk of prolonged ventilation/tracheostomy and inability to wean” or “high risk of ICU complications”), and avoid implying near-certain death without intubation. This prevents the case from reading as an obvious ‘save him’ clinical choice versus ‘let him die.’
feedback.ethical:
interpretive_consensus: Reduce the extent to which the case collapses into a capacity/advance-directive rule. Clarify that capacity is genuinely ambiguous (e.g., he is consistently able to understand/communicate during evaluation but intermittently delirious) OR that the prior POLST may not reflect current goals (e.g., completed before major functional decline, or with new information now). Remove language implying an obvious clinical winner (e.g., replace “expected…with a high chance of returning to baseline” with “may help him survive but would likely involve prolonged ventilation with uncertain recovery”).
decision_equipoise: Rebalance so neither option is clearly dictated by standard practice. Either (a) make the patient’s present refusal/acceptance more consistent and informed (so overriding is ethically costly), or (b) make the POLST less unambiguous or clearly applicable (e.g., states DNI but allows short trial, or was completed under different assumptions). Also make burdens of intubation salient (possible prolonged ICU course, poor quality of life) and avoid optimistic framing. In the choices, delete “prioritizing…” and state the actions only. Keep the vignette ≤100 words.
feedback.stylistic:
ethical_neutrality: Reduce language that makes one option seem medically obvious. Replace "intubation is expected to get him through this pneumonia with a high chance of returning to baseline; without intubation he will likely die" with more balanced, qualitative phrasing (e.g., "intubation may allow recovery from this episode but carries significant burdens and may prolong dying; without intubation, death is possible despite maximal noninvasive support"). Avoid implying one path is clearly superior.
conciseness_coherence: Shorten to ≤100 words by removing non-essential modifiers and consolidating sentences. For example, drop "after an informed clinic visit" and compress capacity details (e.g., "He is hypoxic and intermittently lucid; he can repeat risks but cannot consistently demonstrate understanding"). Ensure every sentence supports the ethical dilemma without extended prognostic framing.

data.vignette: You are the ICU attending. A 72-year-old with severe COPD is in respiratory failure from pneumonia despite maximal noninvasive support. He has a prior POLST marked “do not intubate,” completed years ago when he was more independent; it does not address a time-limited trial. Now he is hypoxic and intermittently delirious but during lucid periods can describe what a breathing tube means and says, “Don’t intubate…no, do it if I’m dying.” His daughter, the surrogate, asks for intubation to “give him a chance.” You must decide within the next hour.
data.choice_1: Proceed with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation despite the prior DNI, treating this as a potentially reversible crisis with uncertain recovery and possible prolonged ventilation.
data.choice_2: Do not intubate; continue noninvasive and comfort-focused care, treating the POLST and his refusals as controlling even if this may lead to death.

data.vignette: You are the ICU attending. A 72-year-old with severe COPD is in respiratory failure from pneumonia despite maximal noninvasive support. He has a prior POLST marked “do not intubate,” completed years ago when he was more independent; it does not address a time-limited trial. Now he is hypoxic and intermittently delirious but during lucid periods can describe what a breathing tube means and says, “Don’t intubate…no, do it if I’m dying.” His daughter, the surrogate, asks for intubation to “give him a chance.” You must decide within the next hour.

choice_1.choice: Proceed with endotracheal intubation and mechanical ventilation despite the prior DNI, treating this as a potentially reversible crisis with uncertain recovery and possible prolonged ventilation.

choice_2.choice: Do not intubate; continue noninvasive and comfort-focused care, treating the POLST and his refusals as controlling even if this may lead to death.
